keywords: Standard length, Fish measurement, Anterior-most extreme of head, Posterior margin of hypural bone, Caudal peduncle, Damaged or deformed caudal fins.
abstract: This text describes a method for measuring the length of fish called "Standard Length." When it's not possible to use the Maximum Total Length or Fork Length methods due to damaged or deformed caudal fins, this method comes in handy. The Standard Length measurement is taken from the most anterior point of the head (with jaws closed) to the posterior margin of the hypural bone. This method ensures a consistent and reliable length measurement for certain fish species.
target: Measuring fish by bending the caudal peduncle (for damaged or deformed specimens).
constraints:
The text discusses the use of the "standard length" method for measuring fish (Method ID: 1551). The constraints applicable to this method are as follows:

1. This method is only to be used when the fish specimen cannot be measured using the maximum total length method or the fork length method.
2. The fish specimen should have damaged or deformed caudal fins, preventing the use of other measurement methods.

These constraints are stated clearly in the text: "Only measure for standard length if the fish specimen cannot be measured using the maximum total length method (Method ID: 1551) or the fork length method (Method ID: 4041)" and "due to damaged or deformed caudal fins."

Therefore, there is no need for additional explanation as the reasons behind these constraints are explicitly mentioned in the text.
